ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle package for 5.1 not available
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks a lot for your empathy. I, being a non-programmer, was thinking that maybe a virtual machine would be a good working solution for many Moodlers who need to test features in a local server . Maybe the wizards at Moodle HQ or very helpful Moodlers can suggest which virtualization product could be best suited for this task. Ideally, it would be best if it could work in both PCs and Macs. Virtualbox , works with both Windows and Mac. I recall it was fairly easy to use (for me) and it could run in a modest harware VMWare , which might be intimidating for a newbee Hyper-V , which is a Microsoft package, is Windows only. Or, maybe the best solution might be to wait patiently for the release of a new MoodleBox software with Moodle 5.1.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle package for 5.1 not available

(I don't know how easy that is for a non-developer, particularly on Windows.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Second Moodle Community Meeting - October 28th, 13:00pm UTC
ResponsesInList.Text: ———Second Moodle Community Meeting October 28th, 1:00-2:00 pm UTC (7-8am, Mountain Standard Time)------- "Best of Mountain Moot” One of the most energizing MoodleMoots on the planet happens each year up in the Rocky Mountains of North America. It is called 'Mountain Moot', which was held for three days in July 2025. Emma Richardson , a Moodle administrator and trainer from a school district in Colorado, has invited Joe Thibault and Claire Kruse to present with her about the “Best of Mountain Moot". This is not a webinar, so turn your cameras on, bring a smile, and join in the active discussion. We will have three discussions, after each presenter. It is not being recorded, so don’t miss the actual face-to-face event. BBB Meeting Link: https://moodle.org/mod/bigbluebuttonbn/view.php?id=8821 Opens ten minutes before 1:00pm UTC. All are welcome, but you may need to enroll in Moodle.org first. And mark your calendars for the future community meetings on the fourth Tuesday of the month. The Third Community Meeting will be hosted by Thomas Neidemeier or Marcus Green. Organized by Harald Schnurbusch, Don Hinkelman, Thomas Neidemeier, Marcus Green, Paul Raper, and Moodle community members across the globe.  This meeting will be in English, but we are open to organizing meetings in other languages as well. ————————————

ResponsesInList.Title: Is Moodle Updates Down?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Guys Spent time this evening trying to overcome this issue. On the notification page when clicking on check for available updates causes this error:- Unable to fetch available updates data - unexpected HTTP response code. I have checked with the host for any DNS issues and they have checked (Hostinger my provider) and they have said that updates.moodle.org is down. They even ran a check at the following and confirmed it was down:- https://testlocal.ly/tests/687034773ef2e183790fbedc However, just wanted to check if this is actually down or is it something that I am seeing only. They have assured me that it is moodle's website and that is why I am getting this error. I have never known Moodle to be down. I even created a php file in my root for a Curltest with the following:- `";` `$ch = curl_init($url);` `curl_setopt($ch, CURLOPT_RETURNTRANSFER, true);` `curl_setopt($ch, CURLOPT_TIMEOUT, 10);` `curl_exec($ch);` `if(curl_errno($ch)) {` `echo "❌ cURL error: " . curl_error($ch) . "
";` `} else {` This then returns the following:- Testing https://download.moodle.org ... ✅ Connection successful Testing https://updates.moodle.org ... ❌ cURL error: Could not resolve host: updates.moodle.org Am i missing something or is moodle updates link down, did try searching but nothing to confirm. I have just updated to Moodle 5.0.1+ (Build: 20250706) but had to manually upload each update as none of the install links would work as part of the upgrade. If anyone can shed any light on this it would be appreciated. Thanks again.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle 5.0 packages for Windows
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, For information about the Moodle 5.0 for Windows package, I used it yesterday to do a local installation on my computer and I encountered a problem with the package's database , which was still in version 10.4.28- MariaDB whereas version 10.11.0 is now the minimum version required when going through the environment page. To be able to continue with the installation, I therefore modified line 4715 of the /admin/environment. xml file as follows: <VENDOR name=‘mariadb’ version=‘10.4.0’ /> I also encountered a problem with the local_adminer plugin. I removed it and reinstalled version 4.17.2 for moodle 4.5. Christian

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle 5.0 packages for Windows
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Christian, Thanks for highlighting the fact that you need to modify the admin/environment.xml file to get the Moodle 5.0 packages for Windows to work. We need to update the text on the pages Moodle packages for Windows and Moodle packages for Mac OS X ( MDLSITE-7977 ).

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle 5.0 packages for Windows
ResponsesInList.Text: The fix used is actually a hack, as described in https://docs.moodle.org/500/en/admin/environment/database/mariadb_(10.4.28-MariaDB ) The complete install package for Moodle must be updated in order to include the needed database. Maybe it merits a tracker issue, as many Moodlers use the complete Windows install package for testing, debugging and translations checking.

I was surprised that the answer was No. In our community courses we accompany them a long time.. not only it gives the participants time to really understand but also all sorts of collaborations outside the course itself happen. But again, we have a local, limited crowd, you have global, unlimited crowd. Thus, understandable.

ResponsesInList.Title: When browsing across community sites, additional characters are added to the page URL
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello everyone, This is to let you know that we’ve created a tracker issue MDLSITE-7913 , based on Visvanath’s comments, to investigate the problem of the additional characters added to URLs when browsing across our community sites. We are also investigating internally the point raised about cookie preferences not saving. We’ll keep you informed when there is progress on these. Regarding the GA4 implementation, this is something that is widely done and that we have implemented to better help us understand how people move between our sites. This in turn will help us improve the user experience. Hopefully this clarifies things. Thank you, Jessica Gramp Moodle Community Manager

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: When browsing across community sites, additional characters are added to the page URL
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello again everyone. I know it's been a while, but it's taken time to investigate. We can now confirm that cookie preferences are saving as intended, so if you want to turn off these cookies, you can do so using the 'Cookies Settings' link in the footer of moodle.org. We are still investigating a fix to the issue of the additional characters added to the moodle.org page URLs, which stops anchors working & causes 404 pages ( MDLSITE-7913) . Please bear with us while we look into this. We will provide an update once we know more. Thank you. Jessica Gramp Moodle Community Manager

ResponsesInList.Title: registration_cron_task failing with hub error
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm running Moodle 3.9.13+ and I noticed that the Site Registration cron task (\core\task\registration_cron_task) is failing and throwing this error each time it tries to run: "An error occurred during registration update (hub/errorconnect)" What does "hub/errorconnect" mean? Is the website not able to connect to the Moodle site registration servers? SELECT * FROM mdl_registration_hubs returns one row with a token and secret and with the confirmed column = 1. When I go to the Registration page in Site Administration in my site I can see my existing site registration details. Pressing the Update Registration button throws another error: "An error occurred during registration update (hub/errorconnect)" My Moodle site is in a DMZ and it's internet facing. I use links in my courses to other sites like youtube.com and none of those sites are blocked. https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=428318 suggests registering and unregistering my site, but the hub/errorconnect error prevents that. What does the \core\task\registration_cron_task Scheduled task do? Does it check my Moodle site version every time it runs? Lastly, could it be my firewall that's blocking the connection to the Moodle registration server ?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: registration_cron_task failing with hub error
ResponsesInList.Text: hello i have the issue,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: registration_cron_task failing with hub error
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, A recent report of updating the site registration failing with the error hub/errorconnect had as cause "a site admin had restricted cURL to specific ports, and it appears that ports 80 and 443 were inadvertently removed. This prevented Moodle from connecting to the hub or other services" (from MDLSITE-7863 ).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: registration_cron_task failing with hub error - things to check
ResponsesInList.Text: Also, for anyone who has the error hub/errorconnect, for a list of things to check see the section '"The hub cannot access your site" or hub/errorconnect' in the documentation Site registration .

ResponsesInList.Title: Can someone delete my plugin's Moodle Documentation page?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I have a Moodle plugin, the Multitopic format, and when I originally released it, I added a Moodle Documentation page stub for it, intending to fill this out later.  I've finally got around to writing some documentation, but on reflection, the Moodle Documentation probably isn't the best place for it, because that has separate versions for each Moodle version, and my plugin's releases aren't synchronised with Moodle versions.  So I've put the documentation elsewhere. These are the Moodle Documentation pages I'm aware of: https://docs.moodle.org/38/en/Multitopic_course_format https://docs.moodle.org/39/en/Multitopic_course_format https://docs.moodle.org/310/en/Multitopic_course_format https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/Multitopic_course_format https://docs.moodle.org/400/en/Multitopic_course_format https://docs.moodle.org/401/en/Multitopic_course_format https://docs.moodle.org/402/en/Multitopic_course_format https://docs.moodle.org/403/en/Multitopic_course_format https://docs.moodle.org/403/en/course/view/multitopic (link) I don't seem to have the rights to delete these, can someone do this for me?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can someone delete my plugin's Moodle Documentation page?
ResponsesInList.Text: I can do that for you James but I think it would be nicer if we keep the pages but instead put a link to your own documentation - so people have the benefit of both. If you can send me the link to your own documentation then I will add the link to those pages, rather than removing them completely.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can someone delete my plugin's Moodle Documentation page?
ResponsesInList.Text: OK, thanks. The Multitopic format documentation is here: https://github.com/james-cnz/moodle-format_multitopic/wiki

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can someone delete my plugin's Moodle Documentation page?

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Groups for Crosslisted Course
ResponsesInList.Text:
The enroll table in moodle creates a reference meta link to the child sections , in order to support crosslisted Course. They make use of the enroll plugin to create a meta link to the child section in moodle enrol table, https://moodledev.io/docs/apis/subsystems/enrol#enrol_plugin-add_default_instance . For creating groups under crosslisted group we move the groups of child section to parent Crosslist , but the
challenge is when we uncrosslist a single child section, the enrollment
& groups remain under the crosslisted course and doesn't move back
to the child course. Any other approach we can take on this issue ? This is what the Group api's support https://moodledev.io/docs/apis/subsystems/group

ResponsesInList.Title: cURL: Error 7 when calling https://download.moodle.org/api/1.3/pluginfo.php
ResponsesInList.Text: Currently getting HTTP status 400 for `https://download.moodle.org/api/1.3/pluginfo.php` . With Moodle 4.1.5+ (Build: 20230929) trying to upgrade a plugin (on `admin/index.php?cache=0&confirmrelease=1&confirmplugincheck=0&confirmupgrade=1` ) I get: cURL: Error 7 when calling https://download.moodle.org/api/1.3/pluginfo.php line 276 of /lib/classes/update/api.php: call to debugging() line 226 of /lib/classes/update/api.php: call to core\update\api->call_service() line 102 of /lib/classes/update/api.php: call to core\update\api->call_pluginfo_service() line 1122 of /lib/classes/plugin_manager.php: call to core\update\api->get_plugin_info() line 1628 of /lib/classes/plugin_manager.php: call to core_plugin_manager->get_remote_plugin_info() line 1238 of /admin/renderer.php: call to core_plugin_manager->available_updates() line 206 of /admin/renderer.php: call to core_admin_renderer->plugins_check_table() line 705 of /admin/index.php: call to core_admin_renderer->upgrade_plugin_check_page() Is this just me? Or a transient issue?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: cURL: Error 7 when calling https://download.moodle.org/api/1.3/pluginfo.php
ResponsesInList.Text:
My mistake, SELinux was blocking the connection attempt. To fix it I needed: 
```text
# setsebool -P httpd_can_network_connect 1


# systemctl restart php-fpm
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Plugin Code no one can copy
ResponsesInList.Text: I have developed one plugin in a Moodle platform and I have to give it to one of my customer and before installing on his environment. I want to secure my code so no one can copy and share with any one.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Plugin Code no one can copy
ResponsesInList.Text: Did you see the License ?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Plugin Code no one can copy
ResponsesInList.Text: you can't - as Visvanath mentions this will be against the GPL license which your code will need to comply with as it will be a copy of Moodle code. The only way to do this is to not give them the code at all, but to host something on your own internal infrastructure that does the work - eg a plagiarism plugin integration for Moodle will connect to an external API/ passing information to the external api and getting a response back. the code that is installed in Moodle is easy to copy, but the integration uses an api key/secret/password to connect to the external API system and users can't access that integration/API without the password, (and it's not code installed on their servers but yours.)

ResponsesInList.Title: New demo sandboxes for supported Moodle LMS versions
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Moodlers, Up to now, the Moodle sandbox was solely in the latest Moodle major version. Thanks to community feedback, the Community Sites team has been working to set up additional sandboxes for supported Moodle versions. These alternative sandbox sites (for Moodle 3.11 and 4.0 at present) can be found as links on the Moodle 4.1 sandbox demo site . You will notice that each sandbox is now also numbered with its Moodle major version. Note that the sandboxes are regularly upgraded and run on the most recent point version. Best regards and happy Moodling! The Community Sites team

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Permalinks sometimes don't work in the Moodle forums

For example, I expect that adding a breakpoint to the JavaScript in web browser developer tools would immediately change the behaviour. Sorry, this is not really a very helpful post.

ResponsesInList.Title: Iframes in MoodleDocs
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Are iframes allowed in MoodleDocs ? I think not. If they were, it might be possible to embed questions into the MoodleDocs documentation, making it more dynamic. The insertion of iframes is possible with the MediaWiki Extension:Iframe ↗ . For security reasons, trusted web servers can be selected from which the iframes could be inserted. Embedding Moodle questions is done using Tim Hunt's excellent Embed questions filter ↗ plugin and using questions from a Moodle site where access is automated. For example, see this Moodle question embedded in a Google Site ↗ .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Iframes in MoodleDocs
ResponsesInList.Text: Awesome work Dominique. Nice to see that that is possible.

ResponsesInList.Title: Non-editing Teacher managing groups from cohorts
ResponsesInList.Text: If a non-editing teacher is part of a cohort, can I make it so that they can put the members of their cohorts into groups themselves? To be specific, I would like them to be able to put the people within their own cohort into a group with the teacher being the teacher and the student(s) being the student(s) without the non-editing teacher being able to see other students/teachers in the system. Can this be done? If so, what do I need to do to get there? Ideally, teachers could be assigned their role within the cohort, students assigned their role within the cohorts, then teachers can choose courses, enroll themselves and their students, then be the teacher of that course for the cohort without being privy to any names of other participants outside of the cohort.

I used to be able to add comments and make small page edits in the Moodle Docs , but since the upgrade to the latest MediaWiki version, I get kicked out when I try to save a comment. Can anyone check if this is an issue easily solved? I wanted to add a note of caution to the page on Import course data , warning users not to import into courses already filled with content, as this seems to merge source and target courses. To my knowledge, the import feature only works as expected when copying into an empty, unedited course.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Docs - cannot edit?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Joost, Sorry to hear you were unable to edit a documentation page. When you say 'I get kicked out' do you mean you become logged out? I just tried editing a page and was able to save my edits without any problem.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Docs - cannot edit?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Docs - cannot edit?
ResponsesInList.Text: I tried with an ordinary account to add a comment on a comments page and then saved my comment. Thus, it remains a mystery why you got logged out. Perhaps you can try in a different browser or a new incognito window?

ResponsesInList.Title: [Moodle Docs] Documentation dev/JMeter, XX/en/Test_course_generator and XX/en/JMeter_test_plan_generator overlapping
ResponsesInList.Text: I have been updating https://docs.moodle.org/dev/JMeter and found that there are two overlapping pages propagating in the user documentation branches: - https://docs.moodle.org/en/Test_course_generator - https://docs.moodle.org/en/JMeter_test_plan_generator Both are rarely updated after the initial work during 2013/14. I suggest redireting them to https://docs.moodle.org/dev/JMeter . I offer to transfer whatever necessary before you set the redirection.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: [Moodle Docs] Documentation dev/JMeter, XX/en/Test_course_generator and XX/en/JMeter_test_plan_generator overlapping
ResponsesInList.Text: I think only https://docs.moodle.org/en/JMeter_test_plan_generator should redirect to https://docs.moodle.org/dev/JMeter https://docs.moodle.org/en/Test_course_generator is an independent feature. What would be useful is to move the section "Make test course" from https://docs.moodle.org/dev/JMeter into https://docs.moodle.org/311/en/Test_course_generator where it really belongs.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: [Moodle Docs] Documentation dev/JMeter, XX/en/Test_course_generator and XX/en/JMeter_test_plan_generator overlapping
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi David Thanks a lot for looking in to this. I had the bad feeling that this is another case of Moodle Docs being left to "organic growth". I went through the three documents (if one counts /en/XX/ as one) again and fundamentally agree on your stand. To be specific: 1. Site administration > Development > Make test course Yes, this is independent of JMeter. Therefore the right document is https://docs.moodle.org/en/Test_course_generator . I will _move_ the content of https://docs.moodle.org/dev/JMeter#Make_test_course to https://docs.moodle.org/en/Test_course_generator and will link https://docs.moodle.org/dev/JMeter#Make_test_course to https://docs.moodle.org/en/Test_course_generator . 2. Site administration > Development > Make JMeter test plan P.S. Since we are at this topic, could you have a look at this enquiry: How are JMeter test courses and test plans are related? https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=423923#p1707636 . Now I know, those to are not directly related. Still the test course generator creates courses with (1, 100, 1 000, 10 000, 50 000, 100 000) users enrolled. The JMeter test plan generator generates plans for courses of (1, 30, 100, 1 000, 5 000, 10 000) users.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: [Moodle Docs] Documentation dev/JMeter, XX/en/Test_course_generator and XX/en/JMeter_test_plan_generator overlapping

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Courses and General Knowledge
ResponsesInList.Text: Good Day, Wondering if you can assist. I am currently enrolled in your Moodle 3.9 course. It is a great course and the fact that I can get a free certificate at the end of the course is even more awesome. I am also enrolled in Moodle Admin basics and Moodle Teaching basics. However, the certification is not free. I have sat in the week one Bluebutton session where it was explained that the course for Moodle 3.9 after this Teaching will also go to the same as Moodle Admin basics and Moodle Teaching in the case of the certification. For example, I know I should set the course duration. But what other things should be taken into consideration or be done before starting a course? Also during the course what should be checked and monitored or be done as an administrator? Thank You

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Learn Moodle Courses and General Knowledge
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Thanks for your interest in the Moodle Basics courses on the Learn Moodle site . From 2021, all courses offered on the site will have an optional certificate for purchase and there will be no more free certificates. This is because we need to raise funds to be able to continue offering training courses for free and to develop new courses. Each course on the site will remain free for you to take and will have a completer badge which you can obtain for free as proof of completion. I am going to move your post to the Moodle community sites forum, as it is about Learn Moodle. Regarding your questions about getting ready for online learning, please ask them in a separate post.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Learn Moodle Courses and General Knowledge
ResponsesInList.Text: I want to learn Development kindly let me know all details that how much time duration of this course & what things properly we learn in this course. Thanks waiting for your response.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Plugin Development Basics course
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Maria, If you sign up for the Moodle Plugin Development Basics course you'll see inside a list of things that you will learn. You can unenrol at any time if you wish. As for how much time the course takes, that is up to you - it is self-paced so you can progress as slowly or as quickly as you like.

ResponsesInList.Title: Дополнения к сертификату
ResponsesInList.Text: Здравстуйте! Я очень рад,  снова продолжить с Вами общения. Прежде  хочу поблагодарить Вас  за наданную возможность учиться и повышать свой уровень. Я с удовольствием прошел курс Moodle Teaching Basics и хотел бы получить сертификат, но есть такая прозьба: Возможно ли в сертификате добавить количество часов, хотя бы  1 кредит - 30 часов. Дело в том что  в Украине, а возможно и в других странах для повышения квалификации преподаватель в университете в сумме должен набрать 150 часов. Сертификаты в которых не указанно количесто часов учебным отледом не принимаются во внимания, а он очень актуальный на сегоднешний день. Благодарю за понимания и доверия к учащимся. С уважением, Сергей.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Дополнения к сертификату
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Sergei and thanks for your comments about Moodle Teaching Basics. We use English here, but if you would like to use a different language there are other Moodle  communities in other languages including Russian and Ukrainian. I agree that it is a good idea to include a number of hours on our certificates and Helen and I will discuss this.  The minimum number of hours recommended for Moodle Teaching Basics is twelve hours so that would be the figure we would add.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Дополнения к сертификату/Certificate addition
ResponsesInList.Text: Здравстуйте Сергiй! В сертификате теперь отображается рекомендуемое количество часов. Вы можете скачать его снова. Hello Sergei. The certificate now displays the recommended number of hours. You can download it again.

ResponsesInList.Title: Suggestion re support for Moodle Workplace
ResponsesInList.Text: Helen and Mary, I notice that there are more and more questions appearing in the general forums these days for features specific to Moodle Workplace. Since very few people in the community at large will have an experience with Workplace, mostly these go unanswered. And even for those of us who do work with Workplace, since we do that through a partner, and all the question posters also are getting some sort of partner support, answering a public question can be a bit tricky. I suggest adding a forum for this, similar to the Moodle Cloud forum, so we could at least direct these posters to a place more likely to get some response. And partner support staff will be able to see these as well and respond or direct users to the proper support channels. As always, thanks! Randy

ResponsesInList.Title: List R/exams under "Useful utilities" in Moodle XML format?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, may I suggest that our R/exams software is listed under "Useful utilities" on the Moodle XML format documentation page? https://docs.moodle.org/39/en/Moodle_XML_format#Useful_utilities A possible brief description (using Markdown format) is: [R/exams]( http://www.R-exams.org/ ) is a one-for-all exams generator that can export Moodle XML (among various other output formats) from potentially dynamic exercises written in R/Markdown or R/LaTeX. A brief tutorial for Moodle is available at: [E-Learning Quizzes with R/exams for Moodle and OpenOLAT]( http://www.R-exams.org/tutorials/elearning/ ). Thanks for your consideration & best wishes, Achim Zeileis
role: Picture of Institut für Statistik Innsbruck

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: List R/exams under "Useful utilities" in Moodle XML format?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Achim for your suggested addition to the Moodle XML format documentation. As Moodle Docs is a wiki that anyone can edit, I'd encourage you to log in (using your moodle.org username and password) and edit the page yourself, then you will be listed as a contributor in the page documentation.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: List R/exams under "Useful utilities" in Moodle XML format?
ResponsesInList.Text: As Helen said, you could have made the addition yourself. To help you, I already did it. Have a look for any correction, so you can be listed as a contributor yourself.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: List R/exams under "Useful utilities" in Moodle XML format?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you so much, Helen and Nicolas, this is highly appreciated! I'm still new to the Moodle community but I'll try to learn about making future contributions and bug reports in the appropriate way. I'm not using Moodle in my own teaching but since the start of the pandemic the interest in (and feature requests for) using R/exams with Moodle increased considerably. So I've worked more with Moodle over the last months.
role: Picture of Institut für Statistik Innsbruck

ResponsesInList.Title: "To post in a forum you first need to become a member of the community."
ResponsesInList.Text: I have been a member of the Moodle forums for a few years, but every so often (it seems to be perhaps every few months or so, perhaps when I have not visited the forums for some time and want to ask a new question), when I try to post a message, I get the following error/warning: "To post in a forum you first need to become a member of the community." If I then follow the "Become member of this community" link, I can indeed then make a post, but I am mildly puzzled as to why this happens. (Only mildly puzzled, I add. If it's just one of those sort of unusual minor bugs, I can live with it…)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: "To post in a forum you first need to become a member of the community."
ResponsesInList.Text: "FIrst become a member of the community" is a rephrasing of the idea that you must be enrolled in the course, and so since you have not logged in for a few months you have been automatically unenrolled. It's not a bug though.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: "To post in a forum you first need to become a member of the community."
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the explanation! It may not be a bug, but it is perhaps a bit of a confusing "(mis)feature", as I didn't realise that the Moodle forums were treated like courses, and you don't normally expect to be "unenrolled" from a forum once you become a member. Maybe it might be useful if there were a note explaining this on the forum site somewhere (apologies if there is and I have not spotted it), to help reduce confusion for less frequent forum users.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Demo courses download
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I am trying to download courses from the Mount Orange School Demo site but there is no option for backups when logged in as a Manager. can someone please tell me what to do? Sohaib

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Demo courses download
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Sohaib, You can backup a course when logged in as a manager by going to the course then in the actions menu (gear icon) select Backup.

ResponsesInList.Title: Cannot register new instance, lost email access
ResponsesInList.Text: We just set up a new Moodle 3.8 instance at moodle.cca.edu but I cannot complete registration because that URL was registered previously. An error message displays that "we've sent an email to this previously registered site administrator" except…I don't know who that would be, we've checked all our relevant email accounts, it's likely it's a developer who has since left our institution. What do we do? I saw that sites with registration problems were recommended to email support@moodle.org, but anything sent there receives and automated reply which seems to indicate it is not monitored by a human being.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Cannot register new instance, lost email access
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Eric, Due to the large volume of messages sent to the moodle.org support email, there is now an automated reply. However, don't worry, as we regularly scan the messages for any registration problems and reply to them personally. Thus, please expect to hear from us shortly!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Cannot register new instance, lost email access
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you! I got a reply saying that our prior registration had been removed and was able to successfully re-register.

ResponsesInList.Title: [MoodleDocs] Where is the table of content?
ResponsesInList.Text: We had similar issues in the past. I remember the answer being a setting in one's profile. Now I view this page as guest https://docs.moodle.org/38/en/File_resource . There is no table of content. But if I add the proper anchor to the URL like https://docs.moodle.org/38/en/File_resource#Files_from_Google_Drive_and_OneDrive , then I'm taken to the right section. Is there a hidden table of content?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: [MoodleDocs] Where is the table of content?
ResponsesInList.Text: A table of contents is automatically added when the page has at least 4 headings. When there are less than 4 headings, a table of contents can be created by adding `__TOC__` to the page. As you've noticed, headings always have anchor links.

ResponsesInList.Title: Editor changed to WYSIWYG.
ResponsesInList.Text: Now, since today(?), I get a WYSIWYG editor when I write in a forum. I am certain that I had "Text areaL editor set in my profile. In fact it changed abruptly. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: The extended forum header is gone!
ResponsesInList.Text: For clarity for readers, the moderators of the forums on moodle.org had the ability to post two different pieces of text in the forum description box - one that displayed at the top of the forum using `div class="intro"` and one that displayed at the top of the page when posting a new item using `div class="posting-intro"` With the changes to the forum activity in 3.7 and the introduction of inline forum posting, the content of the second div (posting-intro) is no longer displayed.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Re: The extended forum header is gone!
ResponsesInList.Text: Indeed. The "extended forum header" is still there in a div class="posting-intro". What a relief!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Re: The extended forum header is gone!
ResponsesInList.Text: As David comments in MDLSITE-5795 , unfortunately there doesn't seem to be an easy solution for displaying posting-intro text when starting a new discussion inline.

If you overwrite the shorter content with the longer content, the problem would be solved!

ResponsesInList.Title: Moving a page in Moodle Documentation wiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I have been composing this documentation page for our new plugin : https://docs.moodle.org/35/en/TeamUp But I finally would like it to be moved to https://docs.moodle.org/3x/en/TeamUp because everything works fine with 3x versions. I also worked on the french page documentation for this plugin, and it took this url while I thought been working on the 35 page : https://docs.moodle.org/3x/fr/TeamUp Are such changes possible ? Any suggestions on good practices to write documentation ? Thanks in advance ;-* Zabelle

ResponsesInList.Title: Docs
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Zabelle. The English language documentation has different wikis for each version, identified by the number in the URL so if you have written your documentation in the 3.5 version then (assuming the plugin is also current for the 3.6 and 3.7 versions) then you would have to rewrite the page separately for those two versions - or we can do it for you if you prefer. When a new version of Moodle comes out the documentation is redirected to the lastest version, so now if you simply type docs.moodle.org/en/Teamup, (with no version number) you will be taken to the latest version which is 3.7. The good news is that, if you add your page to the 3.7 documentation it will be copied over to future versions so you won't need to do it again.) The French language documentation is slightly different because they just have one version, as you have discovered, 3x, for all 3.+ versions of Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Docs
ResponsesInList.Text: That's the thing ! I understand ! I will wait for one collegue to review the English version and then copy the doc in the 36 and 37 workspaspace. Thank you very much for this explanation and for all your work with Moodle doc and videos Mary ;-* Zabelle

ResponsesInList.Title: Mount Orange - Stealth Activities not enabled?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there, It doesn't appear to be possible to avail of Stealth Activities on https://school.demo.moodle.net/ Could this be switched on please? thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Mount Orange - Stealth Activities not enabled?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi there. The reason we didn't enable stealth activities on the School demo site is because we like to leave the site as standard as possible - that is, stealth activities are disabled by default, so we left them disabled. Educators who come to explore Moodle for the first time on the School demo site have plenty of other settings to keep them interested. However, as there is admin access on our Sandbox site, demo.moodle.net , it's fine to enable it there for an hour (and you could even back up and restore some courses from the School demo with user data) if you wanted a more authentic view of stealth activities.

ResponsesInList.Title: Messaging output plugins documentation
ResponsesInList.Text:
Apologies for cross-posting ( https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=351173 ), but I think this may be a more appropriate discussion for the question... Moodle activity plugins can have documentation in Moodledocs that can be linked to from the app screens (e.g. Questionnaire - https://docs.moodle.org/32/en/Questionnaire_module ). This exists in a document structure for this. I
have completed two messaging output plugins that have needed steps to
be documented to make them work. These steps are both for the site
plugin configuration and for the user preference settings. Where is the
best place in Moodledocs to add these pages? mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Messaging output plugins documentation
ResponsesInList.Text: Good question Mike, and apologies for my delay in replying. For documentation of the site plugin configuration, I suggest you do the same as for other messaging output plugins with settings. For example, the Jabber settings page admin/settings.php?section=messagesettingjabber has a ' Moodle Docs for this page link' to http://docs.moodle.org/33/en/admin/setting/messagesettingjabber . The docs page admin/setting/messagesettingjabber then redirects to a docs page with a nice title. For message_slack documentation, you could redirect to docs.moodle.org/en/Slack_message_processor or similar. Any documentation about user preference settings could also be added to docs.moodle.org/en/Slack_message_processor. I'd recommend though that you try to make the user preference settings as intuitive as possible with clear setting names and setting descriptions in the UI, so that users don't feel the need to check the documentation. If all the docs redirecting sounds a bit complicated, please feel free to create a page named the same as your messaging output plugin and start writing documentation there. If you then message me, I'd be happy to sort out the redirects.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Messaging output plugins documentation
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Helen. I'll do that.

ResponsesInList.Title: Adding better search capabilities to docs.moodle.org
ResponsesInList.Text: Searching for non trivial information (peices of code or sentances) on the docs.moodle.org/dev using Mediawiki's own internal search engine does not seem to find anything (in many cases) although it exsit inside the pages. For example, looking for " params_for_js "  returned " There were no results matching the query. " While using DockDuckGo (or Google) return very useful (many) results . So what am I actually suggesting... Embed DockDockGo (or Google) search into the mediawiki's "results" page. especially, when no results can be found by the internal engine. As it seems not everyone aware of the limitation the mediawiki search engine has, and come out with a feeling that the docs.moodle.org is missing valuable information. which it's not!

ResponsesInList.Title: Suggestions for improvements to the Moodleplugins site
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi - I am attaching some suggestions of improvements to the data and layout of the Moodleplugins site. These are based on providing more quality information for each plugin in ways that make it easier for the community to make decisions on the reliability of the plugin. There are essentially two ideas here: 1) Create more automated testing tools for developers to run their plugins through, so that each upload can display those results. 2) Tie functional reviews to the plugin itself rather than the upload, and provide more standardized review sections and categorizations. For the automated tools, we have been expanding out the test features provided by the moodle-plugin-ci plugin. Ideally the results of these tests (or something similar if it exists), could be linked to from each plugin download version. This would require every plugin to go through this process. For the standardized review process, it would be good if we could all agree on standardized sections and meta-data categories. Doing so would enable more future enhancements, including better searching for appropriate plugins. I am providing a link of a brief overview of what we are thinking of, and would love to begin discussions if anyone is interested. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggestions for improvements to the Moodleplugins site
ResponsesInList.Text: 1. More automated tests - Make sure every upload goes through those automated tests (such as Travis). No need for the badges then as it could be safely assumed that before being made available on the plugins database , the tests are passed. Currently I believe only the original submission is tested in this way, so getting every version tested would be a plus. 2. Functionality can sometimes change considerably between versions - so I am not sure at all that moving the reviews to a plugin level rather than for the version is a good idea. More importantly, getting respected reviewers in place to have more reviews available on a wider range of plugins would (for me) be a greater priority than adding to the formality of those reviews - which would appear to be detrimental to getting people to complete reviews in the first place. Could you point out some of the reviews with what you consider good standardized sections and categories that have been contributed to the plugins database? Mike, for the sake of clarity, could you say who 'we' is in relation to this as I notice your membership on the MUA is as an individual member, but you seem to be putting this forward as part of an organisation?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggestions for improvements to the Moodleplugins site
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Mike for these suggestions. Just a quick thought with regards to the automated tests of plugins. All the Travis or Jenkins or Behat or PHP Unit or any continuous testing tools are only as useful as the actual underlying unit test assertions and feature files. Without them, we can only perform syntax checks (lint) and eventually how is the plugin code following the Moodle coding style. Both these are good to have. But they themselves say nothing about whether or not the plugin works with particular version of Moodle, database engine or PHP version. For these things, the plugin maintainer / author has to developer good PHP Unit tests and Behat scenarios. And by good I mean tests with good coverage of the functionality, range of use cases, input parameters combinations etc. Let us not overestimate nice green "build passes" badges. It is easy to write trivial test that never fails and be proud of "all greens" on my plugin page. Said that, my +1 to have this area of the plugins directory improved indeed.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggestions for improvements to the Moodleplugins site
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi David - With respect to the Travis CI tests, the ones we are proposing to use are the ones executed by the moodle-plugin-ci plugin. They test for various code rules and structure, and we're working on improving them further. The tests in there do tests for various versions of Moodle, PHP and database engines. With respect to unit testing and Behat testing, you are correct. The validity of the tests are only as good as the tests themselves. Showing the reports will help plugin users determine how much faith they put in them. I think you're point on badges is a good one, and I think showing the test results for each version is a better choice. As part of my ongoing work, we're going to choose the plugins that are important to the POET members first, and help improve the unit and Behat tests with the developers. As we move forward, hopefully we can increase the number of plugins we help. And I think having some record of reporting will help encourage developers to improve their code and tests, and hopefully get more community involved with that help. We're also looking at what can be done to validate the coverage of the existing tests, although that is a controversial measurement. Is there some way I can help define, design and implement these suggestions beyond this? Mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggestions for improvements to the Moodleplugins site
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi David - Just checking in again. Is there some way I/we can help define, design and implement improvements to the plugins database collaboratively with you? mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggestions for improvements to the Moodleplugins site
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi David - It looks like you are unable to collaborate on plugin database improvements at this time. We will continue to forge ahead with our ideas, getting community involvement and feedback, with the goal of providing an improved, quality-tested plugin database/repository. We will make sure everything we do is publicly available at every step with the hopes of integrating our work back into one system eventually. Hopefully, taking this approach will allow you to participate with minimal interruption to your other work and provide opportunities for you approve and affect the directions we take. Thanks mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggestions for improvements to the Moodleplugins site
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for your offer Mike. We (Moodle HQ) are doing that already. There is a project going on that will soon lead to notable improvements in the plugins directory UI and features offered to both users (visitors) and developers hosting their plugins there. We are not currently seeking for help with it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggestions for improvements to the Moodleplugins site
ResponsesInList.Text: That's awesome. Is there a place we can see what the plans are and follow along with the work being done? This would be of interest to all plugin database users and developers. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggestions for improvements to the Moodleplugins site
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there a place we can see what the plans are and follow along with the work being done? There is indeed. The place is called https://moodle.org/plugins and it has been built and maintained like that since ever.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggestions for improvements to the Moodleplugins site
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi David - I think you misunderstood my question. You said, "There is a project going on that will soon lead to notable improvements
in the plugins directory UI and features offered to both users
(visitors) and developers hosting their plugins there." That was what I was asking about when I asked, "Is there a place we can see what the plans are and follow along with the work being done?". For example, tracker items and/or wiki pages with the improvement plans? mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggestions for improvements to the Moodleplugins site
ResponsesInList.Text: I think I found them? MDLSITE-4335

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Suggestions for improvements to the Moodleplugins site
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Richard - I agree that if we knew all of the plugins had to go through the same set of automated tests, that would solve the problem. But, currently that is not the case, and will take time to make them all go through that. So if there was "proof" of some sort, that would be better. I think the links to the direct output of the Travis CI tests would be best, as it would show what was tested and how it fared. For functionality, while function does change, it usually does not - at least not as frequently as the version uploads. I think there is value in knowing which specific version was used when the review was carried out. And it would be great if there was a mechanism to notify the reviewer when a new version was available so the reviewer could validate/update their review. I think there is value in coming up with some standard methods, but I agree that may be too constricting. Our group is going to continue our work to a common format we'll use, and I'll be able to describe that soon. "We" is POET. You can see the details in my profile. Regards, Mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Where to report PM spam
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mark, For spam messages (or if you notice spam on any other Moodle community site), please email support@moodle.org. We can then block the spammer 's account and delete all the messages they sent so that they don't appear in anyone's messaging history. (The email is mentioned on our contact page ; if you can think of anywhere else it should be mentioned, please let us know!)

ResponsesInList.Title: Error in documentation
ResponsesInList.Text:
In https://docs.moodle.org/30/en/Calculated_multichoice_question_type the second example on the page is incorrect. I tried to see if I could edit it, but I got a you don't have permission to edit message. \( 3x^2 + 5xy + 2y^2 = (3x+2y)(x+y) \) , not \( (3x+y)(x+2y) \) . I followed the advice "if you are not sure where to post, post it here." Sorry if this is not the right place to report this. Showing a formula as a choice In this example, we want the student to demonstrate they know how to correctly factor out a binomial equation. We want every student to have a unique problem to solve. For example the teacher enters the question as: 
```text
Given the binomial equation 3x
2
+5xy+2y
2
, where x = {A} and y={B} how would you simplify it before solving it?
```
 The correct choice would be written: 
```text
This polynomial can be reduced to (3*{A}+{B})({A}+2*{B}).
```
 This choice would display as: 
```text
This polynomial can be reduced to (3+2)(1+4).
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Error in documentation
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Thanks for pointing out an error in the documentation. I have just fixed it. If you notice anything else in the documentation that needs improving, if you log in to the wiki, you'll find you have editing rights. I'll see if we can change the don't have permission to edit message to make this clear.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Error in documentation
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Hellen. And thank you also for showing me how I can correct such errors by logging in to the wiki.

That would be really hard and probably time-consuming, so many other things have higher priority for getting done.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Was there a "Using Moodle databases" forum?
ResponsesInList.Text: There used to be a separate forum for this, but as part of the great forum re-organisation, it was merged into some others, mainly the general developer forum (the old forum was very low traffic). Note that there is always confusion between Moodle's database activity, and the database that Moodle uses to store all the application data. I guess that is inevitable and unsolvable. But, anyway, not having two forums with ' Database ' in the name probably helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Was there a "Using Moodle databases" forum?
ResponsesInList.Text: I think most of the confusion between these two (and a few other forums) is that most people scan not read. When they look for "database" and see "database" as the first word, they may not even look at the 2nd word. I think there was a suggestion to name the forums with category keyword first, like "Activity: Database" and "Moodle core: Database" which would have reduced the confusion but that suggestion was not followed.

ResponsesInList.Title: What is the last post of a discussion thread?
ResponsesInList.Text: Example: Right now, in the "Repositories" forum https://moodle.org/mod/forum/view.php?id=1807 the discussion 'Connection between "slasharguments" and mini-sites?' shows https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=276218&parent=1189601 as the last post. But it needs to be https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=276218#p1189597 . It was saved one minute later. The only confusion I can think of is the following: I started the last post shown in the thread later, but edited the should-be-last-post even later.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the last post of a discussion thread?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Visvanath, Are you referring to the same issue as this earlier one ? If not perhaps you are reffering to the long standing problem where by a post is edited after its posted and then the times get changed?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: What is the last post of a discussion thread?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Dan No, I don't think there is a connection to 'In forums in "Moodle in English" last post is the first post for visitors!' https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=270896 . (Which is not solved in my view. Will write there later.) But there may be a connection to this: "Posts no longer indented in long discussion threads on moodle.org" https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=270878 . Anyway, to put the question in more general terms: Let's say there is a discussion thread in moodle.org, which has this tree structure once in drop down at the top "Display replies in nested form" is selected. Let's also say, person A starts reply to the last post in that tree and submits it at t=T. A person B has also started replying to a post at the middle of the tree and submits it at t=T+1. Then person A saw a typo and edited his post and submitted it at t=T+1. The question: Which post would you expect to be shown at the last post in the forum overview? I would say the post by person A. From the example I gave earlier, you can see that moodle.org shows forum post B as the last post in the thread.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle 2.5 documentation coming soon
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everyone, As you've no doubt heard, Moodle 2.5 is due for release next month, and so we're currently working on documenting all the new features and improvements in the new Moodle Docs 2.5 . The wiki includes a new page, New features , which provides screenshots and a quick overview of features of interest to teachers, students and administrators, complementing the more technical Moodle 2.5 release notes . There's also a German Moodle Docs 2.5 , which Gisela is working on (many thanks). Help with the docs is always welcome - just log in with your moodle.org username and password to edit pages. Please see the list of tracker issues labeled 'docs_required' for new features and improvements awaiting documentation.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Plugins forums notifications
ResponsesInList.Text: Derek - I wonder if you might provide some use cases where other types of notification would be helpful. For me the question is a little bigger in terms of how to push out information in a meaningful/useful way to folks about the plugins. For example, might a site admin who has installed a plugin want to receive comments or information that a review has been posted? Thanks for helping us to understand how notifications might actually be used. The great thing now is that we have a tool that we can continue tweaking to meet our needs. Peace - Anthony

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Plugins forums notifications
ResponsesInList.Text: Cool Anthony . A great question. You know my efforts to get a few ( IMO ) basic functionalities into Moodle core over the years - my first e-mail to you was over four years ago I believe.  In many cases (most cases), no joy, and the official word from MoodleHQ is plugins is the way to go, and the new plugins database, and the option to install without server access.  (BRING IT ON!!) This I can live with.  I now will very rarely work with a Moodle hosting provider who does not offer the chance to install plugins for a reasonable cost.  My preference is like the R-L approach here: http://www.remote-learner.co.uk/content/approved-moodle-modules-and-plugins like a whitelist.  Took me a while to find some providers who were proactive in this respect. We choose plugins with care.  Is there likely to be a LONG wait for an upgrade to a new version of Moodle?  Are they likely to go bust?  Are they likely to remove functionality (which has happened) or ignore minor bugs?  Do they answer questions?  Are they well designed? Plugin communuication is spread across many areas: docs, forums, tracker and plugin database, blogs, GIT , PM, email.  If I have some level or responsibility for a site with plugins then I want to know everything that is going on.  So along comes a channel I cannot monitor (the plugins database).  Very frustrating.  I ask a question, how do I know if there is an answer?  Someone else asks a question I know the answer to - How do I know?  Comment from the maintainer - how do I know? A few other items: Comments threaded view? I can handle NOT having threaded views. No WYSIWYG or image insertion. Would be better with this. Reviews. Not really worried about this at the moment.  The discussion around this is unfinished.  (I asked questions about the purpose of reviews etc and I got a sort of answer about who is trusted to write.)  This may be an experiment that failed from my point of view, but it could change. Stats. Cool Documentation. I can live with what is there.  No documentation: I will either write some or e-mail the writer of the plugin or something and if no response I just won't bother with the plugin . . .  This is almost never an issue, even with comments and notes a bit scattered. That's just my case.  The ecosystem around Plugins then has become important to me.  I would like to be able to subscribe to the forums in the plugins database to save having to go back there a lot .  .  . -Derek

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Plugins forums notifications
ResponsesInList.Text: Ah this is exactly what i'm working towards to improve!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Plugins forums notifications
ResponsesInList.Text: Anthony, did you read my comments? Do you need any greater clarity? -Derek

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using Moodle course layout change

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using Moodle course layout change
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Perhaps i'm not like other people, but i'm not afraid at all of SoD (scroll of death), but i really don't like to do multiple clicks before going to the place i need ! SoD has it's pro (for the end user) : you can see all that exists on one page you can use mouse roll (or other scrolling method) to go fast to another place bottom (or up) on the page you can search the page to find fast what you want you can print the whole information in 1 time What do you really gain removing SoD, and having content on several pages ? the page is smaller Yes, it's less server ressources used, but only in first time, because you then have to load the other parts you really want to see... Séverin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using Moodle course layout change
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks everyone for your feedback and apologies for things not being so clear in MDLSITE-1888 . Forums and course sections are listed here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/ccc?key=0AmamVlPpCnn4dGtUY0ZTTkRYb2QxSS1EMnJPY3ZqbWc#gid=2 Each section will have a summary describing what's inside, as in the Deutschsprachiges Moodle course. Séverin, you're right that the scroll of death does have some advantages. If it seems that the one section per page course layout isn't working out, we can switch back, or perhaps make use of a new course format. Also, don't worry, it won't look like the clone site! Up to now we've just used the clone site for testing various bits of code; it's not yet been set up with the new design. Apologies for running way behind the schedule announced by Martin. I'll post to let you all know when the site is ready for feedback. One improvement I'm looking forward to being implemented is having forum posts rated as useful being displayed on the front page of moodle.org in a visitor's own language, together with a link to the community discussion course in that language. Thus, visitors should easily be able to find help in their own language, and not need to hunt through dropdown menus.

ResponsesInList.Title: How & where do I report technical issues?
ResponsesInList.Text: I have been a moodle user for three semesters now & I began having problems with spell check in my discussion forums today. I have attemtped to use this feature in 3 browsers and have failed to be able to use it in all three. IE , Firefox , & Chrome. Please let me know who to report this too if I do not report it here. Thank you!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How & where do I report technical issues?
ResponsesInList.Text: You can definitely post your problems to the forums and hope that a user maybe has a fix for you.  The best way is to start by searching on spellcheck, for example and see what other issues people are having. If it is determined to be a bug, then you file a bug report in tracker.moodle.org or, if someone else has already filed a bug report, vote for theirs. This is open source software and there is no technical support as such but the forum users and moodle regulars tend to be as helpful as they can!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How & where do I report technical issues?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks so much! I will do that now!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How & where do I report technical issues?
ResponsesInList.Text: From the http://moodle.org site if you go to -> Support -> Forums you get the full list of support forums. The course we are in, "Using Moodle" http://moodle.org/course/view.php?id=5 , is the main discussion "Forum" in englsh. Unfortunately, it is not that easy to find the correct forum from there in those close to 100 links to individual forums. For a general inquiry like this the forum "Moodle design" http://moodle.org/mod/forum/view.php?id=7135 is the right place. You can find more about the structure of "Using moodle" in that forum, especially in the discussion "Ideas needed: moodle.org improvements" http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=196302 . P.S. I will soon move this post to the "Moodle design" forum (from "Hardware and Performance").

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle documentation: Error in documentation for "answernumbering" element in Moodle XML?
ResponsesInList.Text: On this page: http://docs.moodle.org/23/en/Moodle_XML_format , in the discussion of multiple choice questions, it says: "answernumbering (allowed values: 'none', 'abc', 'ABCD' or '123')" I am curious why you have 'abc' and '123', but 'ABCD' for capital letters. Is this a documentation error, or is Moodle deliberately being inconsistent?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: Error in documentation for "answernumbering" element in Moodle XML?
ResponsesInList.Text: It is because MySQL thinks 'abc' and 'ABC' are the same string, so the two strings need to differ by something more than case. Hence the option upper case letters for each choice is ABCD. The docs are correct.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle documentation: "Allow extended characters in usernames" info
ResponsesInList.Text: After quite some time testing and research, I finally found MDL-16919 , where it was stated that  uppercase letters are not allowed in the usernames, no matter what (so not a bug, but a feature ;)) Can we please modify the lang string for this info on Site Policies? Current: Allow extended characters in usernames: Enable this setting to allow students to use any characters in their usernames (note this does not affect their actual names). The default is "false" which restricts usernames to be alphanumeric lowercase characters, underscore (_), hyphen (-), period (.) or at symbol (@). Based on whatver is written now, one can falsely assume that if the setting is enabled, then Uppercase letters will be allowed. Which is not the case. Users will be able to use any special characters #$%^, etc,  but still NOT the uppercase letters in the usernames.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: "Allow extended characters in usernames" info
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Elena and all I think the problem is not of documentation but having a clear idea how the final system should be. Historically user names in Moodle are not case sensitive. This is a big obstacle in moving to any standardized character set. One needs to discuss and define the future system before documenting and implementing! See a related discussion, "(Moodle 2.1.2) Problem with Unziping zip files that contain special characters" http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=190958 .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: "Allow extended characters in usernames" info
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all I don't know how to interpret the silence. Here's a second try, a POSIX like suggestion, in spite of the danger of being called a troll a second time http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=190958#p831105 . Allowed characters in usernames:

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: "Allow extended characters in usernames" info
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Visvanath, Given my experience with users, I guess accepting upper case letters (making usernames case sensitive) would tend to complicate things a bit. Maybe they should be allowed at the entry box but then lower-cased before storing them. About the allowed characters, I would add the plus sign, as it is an allowed email address character. In fact, I use quite a lot when registering at some sites.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: "Allow extended characters in usernames" info
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Guillermo > accepting upper case letters (making usernames case sensitive) would tend to complicate things a bit. Maybe they should be allowed at the entry box but then lower-cased before storing them. This is the present logic, at least in Moodle 1. This has its own problems. a) Can you extend that to utf-8? b) There were people who expected the same logic for passwords, i.e. case insensitive! > I would add the plus sign, as it is an allowed email address character. In fact, I use quite a lot when registering at some sites. I have personally nothing against, if it works everywhere. For example all the authentication systems Moodle supports must understand the + and all third party modules, plug-ins, etc. too.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle documentation: Documentation Server_Cluster
ResponsesInList.Text: What is the states of this series of articles: - http://docs.moodle.org/19/en/Server_cluster - http://docs.moodle.org/20/en/Server_cluster - http://docs.moodle.org/21/en/Server_cluster - http://docs.moodle.org/21/en/Server_cluster ? The history pages show that it is the same article which began "11:29, 9 March 2009 chris collman" and cloned sometime after "20:40, 5 March 2010 Manuel de la Torre". But the page comments to /19/ http://docs.moodle.org/19/en/Talk:Server_cluster says, "When I have more time I will update this page with more information (most likely the real-world experience that we had here in San Francisco State University) - Wen 19:02, April 17, 2008 Wen Hao Chuang". How come the history begins on 5 March 2010? I thought during cloning the comments too were duplicated, or am I mistaken? In any case, what I wanted to know is the status of this article which belongs to the category "Performance"? I don't see any useful information in those few lines. I left a comment to that effect in the talk page on 18 Nov 2010, nobody replied.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: Documentation Server_Cluster
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Visvanath, Apologies for not noticing your talk page comment before now. I've just replied to it. As you've noticed, there are no talk page comments in the 2.1 wiki onwards. This is because the majority of comments in the 2.0 wiki were about things which had already been done and thus were no longer relevant, and so we decided not to copy talk pages when creating the 2.1 wiki.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: Documentation Server_Cluster
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Helen Thanks for the reply. But I can't see any change. You wrote in the talk page, "I agree that the contents of Server cluster can be added to the performance documentation and a redirect added.", but apart from that all the aricles I've linked in my previous post are still the same. All "performance" articles, - http://docs.moodle.org/19/en/Performance - http://docs.moodle.org/20/en/Performance_recommendations - http://docs.moodle.org/21/en/Performance_recommendations - http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/Performance_recommendations still have a link to the corresponding - http://docs.moodle.org/19/en/Server_cluster - http://docs.moodle.org/20/en/Server_cluster - http://docs.moodle.org/21/en/Server_cluster - http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/Server_cluster None of them contain any useful information.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: Documentation Server_Cluster
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Visvanath, I have now made sure that the info from the server cluster page is included in the performance recommendations and have redirected the server cluster page in the 2.1 and 2.2 Moodle Docs . (When I add a comment about a suggested change to a talk page, I generally wait a while rather than immediately making the change, in case others have further comments, or the person who wrote the documentation wishes to make the change.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: Documentation Server_Cluster
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Helen You wrote Monday, 9 April 2012, 12:58 PM: > I have now made sure that the info from the server cluster page is included in the performance recommendations and have redirected the server cluster page in the 2.1 and 2.2 Moodle Docs. Yes, http://docs.moodle.org/21/en/Server_cluster and http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/Server_cluster now display the corresponding "Performance recommendations". Still two problems: - Though the content is "Performance documentation" the URL remains "Server_cluster". Is there a way of a changing that too? - The content has gone under "See also". Shouldn't there be a subsection with matching title? > (When I add a comment about a suggested change to a talk page, I generally wait a while rather than immediately making the change, in case others have further comments, or the person who wrote the documentation wishes to make the change.) So far no further editing happened in http://docs.moodle.org/19/en/Server_cluster resp. http://docs.moodle.org/20/en/Server_cluster . I think it is now ok for similar changes as above in http://docs.moodle.org/19/en/Performance and http://docs.moodle.org/20/en/Performance_recommendations .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: Documentation Server_Cluster
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Visvanath, The redirect page with Server_cluster in the URL could be deleted (there are no pages in the wiki linking to it) though perhaps it's best not to in case there are links to it elsewhere, such as forum posts. Performance recommendations now has a subsection titled 'Server cluster'. I think that's what you meant, but if not, please feel free to edit the page and change it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: Documentation Server_Cluster
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Helen, Yes, under the present concept I expected - the contents of http://docs.moodle.org/19/en/Server_cluster to be moved to http://docs.moodle.org/19/en/Performance and the link to be redirected to http://docs.moodle.org/19/en/Performance#Server_cluster . Similarly, - http://docs.moodle.org/20/en/Server_cluster to be replaced by http://docs.moodle.org/20/en/Performance_recommendations#Server_cluster - http://docs.moodle.org/21/en/Server_cluster to be replaced by http://docs.moodle.org/21/en/Performance_recommendations#Server_cluster - http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/Server_cluster to be replaced by http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/Performance_recommendations#Server_cluster Please understand that I am not saying they _have_ to be that way. It is just more convenient for me to provide such links in the discussions rather than collecting the pieces from various places.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle documentation: documenting hacks and alterations
ResponsesInList.Text: What is the best way to document hacks and code alterations? I mean, if i added some functions, it is very much easy to just comment and put the parameters, return, its objective and all... If we altered the core and stuff like that, what is the best way to document them?
role: Picture of Trolling in the Deep

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: documenting hacks and alterations
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, if at all possible don't do that. If you really must do that, then use a good version control system (=== git ) to track you changes. Also, consider a commenting convention to mark the changes inline too.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle documentation: First letter case-sensitivity
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there a reason behind configuring Moodle docs MediaWiki to have first letter case-sensitivity (via $wgCapitalLinks )? I set up an interwiki link between my MediaWiki site and Moodle docs, and was disappointed to find [[md:Backup]] and [[md:backup]] point to two different places. My interwiki link URL is http://docs.moodle.org/en/$1 . So the two URLs expand to: http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/Backup and http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/backup Granted, it's just a minor annoyance to type [[md:Backup|backup]] to get the lowercase link text, but it seems unnecessary. What am I missing? Thanks, Ted

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: First letter case-sensitivity
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ted, Moodle Docs has had first letter case-sensitivity since it was started. As I understand things, changing it now would break tons of links. Is this correct?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: change to Manager account
ResponsesInList.Text: Are you talking about this Moodle site or your own Moodle site? If you mean your own site you are either an admin and so you can already develop courses or else you will need to ask your admin to give you teacher or course creator rights. But if you mean this Moodle site we are on now, well sorry; this is not for you to develop courses - it is for people to ask questions about Moodle and download it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle documentation: "Invalid JSON string" in docs
ResponsesInList.Text: I discovered "Invalid JSON string" had no hits in the docs but scores on the forums and tracker. O added an FAQ as a bit of a laceholder in case someone can write something both clear and authoritative: http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/File_picker_FAQ#How_can_I_solve_the_.22Invalid_JSON_string.22_error.3F It did get me curious, that I knew very little about why this error keeps re-surfacing, now on several versions of Moodle 2+ and several servers. Two random forum discussions that show the comlexity of the issue: http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=183878 http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=182366 It seems the error is a very general one and can cover up a lot of difference causes.  Anyone is welcome to add to the FAQ -Derek

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle documentation: Footnotes in MediaWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Which of these methods work on Moodle Docs http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Footnotes ? Are there any examples? My quick tests were not really helpful.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: Footnotes in MediaWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: A solution like the ref tag would also be very useful for external links. I would go for the following system: In the text itself "anchors" are placed next to the term which needs an external reference. e.g. Ubuntu Server [1] LTS .... (only [1] is a hyperlink, preferably in superscript, which takes one to the line at the bottom of the page) ... [1] Ubuntu Server http://www.ubuntu.com/business/server/overview (only the URL in the above line is an hyperlink pointing to what it stands).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: Footnotes in MediaWiki
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks to this post http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=196748#p859193 got it clarified. The ref and references tags do exactly this, but not on Moodle Docs. Tested them on the original wikipedia.org and work as documented here http://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Extension:Cite/Cite.php .

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle documentation: How to start Moodle documentation in Bulgarian?
ResponsesInList.Text: I would like to contribute to Moodle Documentation in Bulgarian. How can I do that?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: How to start Moodle documentation in Bulgarian?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Vanyo, Thanks for your offer of helping with Moodle documentation in Bulgarian. We've found from experience that for Moodle Docs in other languages to be a success, there needs to be a lot of people wishing to contribute. Thus, if you've not done so already, please post in the Bulgarian community discussion course and ask if anyone else is interested in creating Moodle documentation in Bulgarian. Another thing you could do is make sure all the help strings in Moodle are translated into Bulgarian, as teachers generally click on help buttons before checking the documentation.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: How to start Moodle documentation in Bulgarian?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you Helen, I understand that and I will do what you advise me.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle documentation: Suggestion for the documentation related to the installation.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: Suggestion for the documentation related to the installation.
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Roberto, Thanks for the hint. You're welcome to add this link yourself as Moodle Docs is a wiki and as such free to edit for everyone ;-) You can use the wiki syntax for easy linking to another page in the same wiki. Just put the title of the page in double square brackets. This syntax will also work here in the forums: [[Masquerading]]. You can also directly link to a specific section: [[Apache#Reverse Proxy]]. hth Frank

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle documentation: Where is the 1.9 version of the developer docs?
ResponsesInList.Text: The developer docs are now getting updated from 1.9 to 2.0 by all and sundry (a good thing of course). However, where is the 1.9 version now? There are still those of us who will be developing custom code for 1.9 for some time to come and it's really important that these docs remain available.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: Where is the 1.9 version of the developer docs?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Howard. The plan is to keep only one version of the Dev docs. Within that there will be information about current and previous versions, sometimes within a single page with version identifiers, and sometimes one separate linked pages with older versions marked as obsolete. We don't intend to take away old documentation. One thing I still have to do is redirect Developer documentation from the 1.9 User docs to the new Dev docs. Michael;
