ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle documentation: Moodle Documentation (corrections...)
ResponsesInList.Text: In the Administration / Installation (French) Module, you read: 2. Télécharger le logiciel Il y a deux façons d'obtenir Moodle : par téléchargement d'un fichier compressé ou à l'aide du CVS . Toutes deux sont expliquées en détail sur la page de téléchargement http://moodle.org/download/ . Après avoir téléchargé et décompressé l'archive ou obtenu les fichiers par CVS, vous aurez sous les yeux un dossier nommé « moodle », contenant un certain nombre de dossiers et de fichiers. Vous pouvez placer ce dossier intégralement dans le dossier documents de votre serveur web. Dans ce cas, le site Moodle sera accessible à l'adresse http://votreserveur.com/moodle/ . Vous pouvez aussi copier le contenu de ce dossier dans le dossier documents de votre serveur. Dans ce cas, le site Moodle sera accessible simplement à l'adresse http://votreserveur.com/ . You should correct it as: 2. Télécharger le logiciel Il y a deux façons d'obtenir Moodle : par téléchargement d'un fichier compressé ou à l'aide du CVS. Toutes deux sont expliquées en détail sur la page de téléchargement http://moodle.org/download/ . Après avoir téléchargé et décompressé l'archive ou obtenu les fichiers par CVS, vous aurez sous les yeux un dossier nommé « moodle », contenant un certain nombre de dossiers et de fichiers. Vous pouvez placer ce dossier intégralement dans un répertoire "moodle" de la racine de votre serveur web. Dans ce cas, le site Moodle sera accessible à l'adresse http://votreserveur.com/moodle/ . Vous pouvez aussi copier le contenu de ce dossier directement dans la racine de votre serveur. Dans ce cas, le site Moodle sera accessible simplement à l'adresse http://votreserveur.com/ . Cheers.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle documentation: login.php: Polishing of "Steps for new account creation"
ResponsesInList.Text: I polished the Japanese version of the "Steps for new account creation", and the changes have already been accepted into the CVS . Some of my students found the explaination of the steps for new account creation difficult to understand, because they have so little experience with computers or the internet. While most of the editing was simplifying and clarifying the Japanese, I made a structural change that may be helpful for the English too. Seven seperate steps were too many for my students to conceptualize, so I broke it down into the three main steps . This may be helpful for English speakers as well, so I tried to adapt the simplified version from Japanese back into English: Hi! For full access to courses you'll need to take a minute to create a new account for yourself on this web site. A course may also have a one-time "enrolment key." Here are the steps: 1. Create Account Fill out the New Account form with your details. 2. Confirm Account An email will be immediately sent to your email address. Read your email, and click on the web link it contains. Your account will be confirmed and you will be logged in. 3. Enrol in Course Select the course you want to participate in. If you are prompted for an "enrolment key," use the one given by your teacher. This will "enrol" you in the course. This will enrol you in the course, so can now access the full course. From now on you will only need to enter your personal username and password (in the form on this page) to log in and access any course you have enrolled in.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle documentation: Could we get a new forum and/or resource?
ResponsesInList.Text: I'd like to see Mark Stevens' workshop handout alluded to in http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=18112 included here on the doc Project site as a resource. This got me to thinking about all the others that folks have worked on (like Marguerite's horticulture piece at cornell -and Martin's request that she host it herself and provide a link). Obviously it becomes a burden on the .org admins to deal with versions, updates, typos, etc.. .and not practical for them to give teacher rights to every person who puts together a nice little piece of documentation or supporting material. At the same time, hosting locally has its drawbacks- especially when you consider server rights, movement of faculty, and that sort of thing. So could we get a new forum here that is specifically for such things (either as attachments, or hyperlinks to pages/files)?  This particular forum could allow for larger attachments, and then follow-ups (like notifications of typos, suggestions, etc...) could easily be replies to the corresponding post. Please let me know if this is doable, and how I can help. d.i.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: Increasing file upload size
ResponsesInList.Text: I am a newbie when it comes to Moodle, but I did figure out how to modify the max upload settings. This is for those that don't have Apache2. I'm also using the Debian package for moodle, so there could very well be other differences I'm unaware of. Edited: /etc/php4/apache/php.ini Modified: upload_max_filesize = 2M post_max_size = 8M Edited: /etc/moodle/apache.conf Modified: php_value upload_max_filesize 2M php_value post_max_size 2M Then I restarted Apache . /etc/init.d/apache force-reload

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle documentation: Special phrases in Moodle

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: Special phrases in Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Radik, I've been working in the workshop translation, and "Error Banded" (if I'm not mistaken) is  only a style of grading (in workshop module!!). You can set up lots of yes/no expectations for an assigment: "yes" if the element is there (so a credit would be given) or "no" if the element doesn't appear in your assignment (so any credit wolud be given for that part of the assignment). The number of errors is the proporcional sum of the items that aren't in the assignemet. You can also have a look at Moodle teacher's manual (contributed by Matt Riordan), and you'll find exemples of this style of grading. Hope I've been useful!! clara.

ResponsesInList.Title: Svar: Re: Extended profile
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Sean Thanks for your response. I'll try to answer your question as best I can. First of all - this forum is for the development of a tutorial for teachers so they can learn to use Moodle, primarily as a technical platform - and that will then logically lead to using the platform pedagogically. So I think your question belongs e g in the Moodle forum for teaching strategies. To my experience one difficulty (amongst many) when you want to study or evaluate online education is getting access. In many cases you would have to enroll as a student in order to find out what's 'inside' so to speak. With a scientific approach you might be allowed to do research having access to key persons behind the education and then you could reach a deeper understanding of content, structure, didactic strategies etc. Personally I think that education should be planned, not as standardized and for mass distribution, but rather as adapted to the context , the current situation, well-defined goals and unique target groups. The teacher/educator/coach etc under such circumstances needs to be one of the main course developers together with a network of colleagues and people with various kinds of expertise. This is a huge undertaking for which you need a lot of (pedagogical) knowledge and experience, time and a flexible platform for distribution of education. In my opinion Moodle fills many of the requirements for such a platform. Within the Moodle community some people have suggested the exchange of courses, content of courses, parts of courses and perhaps the mutual development of courses. That is to say not just Open Source but Open Course as well. Why not? The Moodle community is still a young one though so it will probably take some time before we get there, provided people want to go in that direction. Down below here I have collected some web addresses that should be relevant for your needs but I have not checked all of them myself very thoroughly. The first one is to the IT-center of Stockholm. http://itc.edu.stockholm.se/flex/ They offer the kind of courses you describe. The site is in Swedish but you can, if you like, log in as a guest 'gäst', choose a course 'kurs' e g English A 'engelska A' , and then go to course 'till kurs'. From there you can study how the course is organized. Choose part of course 'Välj kursavsnitt'. From then on they communicate in English as well. I think they have a good standard structure for their courses. How it works in practice I don't know. In the case of Stockholm they have created their own platform and they have their own servers and all. Another municipality in Sweden used a commercial platform. When their supplier went bankrupt they became aware of the problem of dependency Here are some more adresses, the first three are general, the others more specific. Cheers, Anders B http://www.languagepilot.com/ http://www.maps2anywhere.com/Languages/languages.htm http://www.college.ch/php-robot/forms/google_ec.php http://www.bbc.co.uk/languages/french/index.shtml http://www.search1web.com/html/links2/11/ http://www.word2word.com/coursead.html http://www.yourdictionary.com/grammars.html

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: Inserts
ResponsesInList.Text: It's not possible to list meanings for all the substitute variables, because they aren't consistent - it depends on the context of each string . You cannot take variables from one place and apply them in another. Even if you could it would make the translations very incompatible with each other. Are you using the online web editor? The idea is that the variables are fairly self-documenting ... just look at their English equivalent and you should see what the substitute phrase/word is.

ResponsesInList.Text: tx Martin. Thats a good and easy Solution for my Problem.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle documentation: extra help for "Search Forums"
ResponsesInList.Text: I would like to propose to place a (?) help link next to the "Search Forums" box to tell the users that they can use the wildcards % and _ in their search. _ stands for any single character and % stands for any number of characters. In particular this can be used to search for topics that contain two words. For example 'help%search' will find all topics that contain 'help' AND THEN 'search'. Internally to Moodle this search is done as an SQL search using LIKE. Perhaps LIKE can do more than I described above. Does anyone know? Can it perhaps even do boolean searches?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: extra help for "Search Forums"
ResponsesInList.Text: I hadn't even noticed this could be done. It's not a good idea to let the raw insertion of the string continue - instead there should be a better defined way of specifying searches (a la Google) from which the SQL string is built up internally. Help wanted on this one (there's bound to be PHP code out there already for this).

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle documentation: Moving and Multiple Moodles
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi All, I have been playing around with Moodle on a Red Hat server at home for a little while now. I have just signed up with a commercial hosting ISP and would like to copy/move all my moodle files from my box to the host server. I 'think' that I have a good idea of what I need to do, but before I start FTP 'ing and SQL 'ing I was wondering if anyone has done this before ? And if you have, is there any documentation ? If not, would it be worth me creating a step-by-step guide ? I would also like to eventually run a number of totally distinct moodle instances on the one server. The 'wimps' way would be to just run seperately directory trees, but has anyone tried to seperate just the config files and share a common code base. Thanks all, David

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: Moving and Multiple Moodles
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi David, Question: &quot ...is there any documentation ? If not, would it be worth me creating a step-by-step guide &quot ? Haven't seen any docs on this. Documentation is always worth it. Thanks David. Question: &quot ...but has anyone tried to seperate just the config files and share a common code base &quot I'd like to see how this turns out, too... John

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle documentation: Moving and Multiple Moodles
ResponsesInList.Text: I have done this several times as follows: 1. Backup the existing moodle file (tar cvf moodle.tar moodle) 2. Backup the database (I use webmin but you can use the Database admin module Martin provides) 3. Backup the moodledata file ( tar cfv moodledata.tar moodledata) FTP the files to the new server: 1. FTP moodle.tar to the web home directory and (tar xvf moodle.tar) 2. Create a moodle database in MYSQL and restore the backup database. 3. FTP moodledata to your home directory and (tar xvf moodledata.tar ) 4. Go to the config.php file and update with the information of the new server. And everything should work OK providing your new server meets the requirements as stated in the install documentation.
